instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD: What is PP0V9_SSD? PP0V9_SSD is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .
definitions.0V9_SSD: What is 0V9_SSD? This is a power rail that powers the SSD..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP2V7_NAND: What is PP2V7_NAND? PP2V7_NAND is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
This arrived fully functional. User wanted their drive erased and a new OS installed.

Booted into OS recovery mode and erased the SSD. During the erase process the screen went black but then nothing else happened. Normally it would turn back on and start internet recovery process.

When trying a DFU restore apple configurator2 keeps giving error message

“The system cannot be restored on this device” unexpected device state DFU expected recovery (probably forced into DFU mode externally” (4014


how do you fix this kind of problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: Check if SSD gets all voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
The issue recently got worse.

After taking board out of the case its now stuck at 5V 0 amp

0V PP3V3 and 0V <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> no shorts.

Tried a new <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> but no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 0.160V

Tried new <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> but no change. Not shorted either.

Any ideas?

Having difficulty finding where to measure SSD voltages. 01521board view for SSD voltage locations much different then this one

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL> appears to be missing but the schematic does not tell me from where it comes from.

On another board that has ticking CPU this rail jumps to 0.160V at times. The one are working on stays at 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>0V9_SSD</SIGNAL>, if missing.
It is generated by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (PMIC).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: 0.472 diode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
So the Apple Configurator 2 tells you machine is in Recovery mode?
We have few recent posts about switching to DFU in such case.

Did you follow all the steps from DFU tutorial?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: No Apple configuator 2 rcognizes the machine in DFU mode, starts the restore process then gives the following error. See attached picture

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: Can't read anything there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: Try this

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: Check if all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are stable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.2V

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 0.755v

PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE 0.802v

<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0.800v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8v

<SIGNAL>PP1V25_SLPS2R_SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> 0.234v

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V25_SLPS2R_SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> 0.234v"
There is a problem.
Check diode mode to ground.
Remove <CAPACITOR>C4781</CAPACITOR> and check voltage again.
If still low, change <CHIP>U4780</CHIP>.

Just in case, try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
After removing and replacing <CAPACITOR>C4781</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>PP1V25_SLPS2R_SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> is now a steady 1.1V

afterwards tried DFU restore once again which finished successfully but the board is still having a boot problem. When plugging in it would go up to 0.78 amps the fan would spin real fast then would go back to 0amps andkept repeating that process.

Tried DFU restore once again but it’s now giving me that same 4014 error along with a new error at times I’ve attached.

What next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
After many attempts apple configurator 2 successfully restored the t2 firmware.

Now when power is applied it goes to 20v and up to 0.78amps before cycling back to 0 and repeat. Fan spins for a few seconds during this process

What should be checked next for the looping problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD</SIGNAL> 1.8V

<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL> 1.054V

<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND</SIGNAL> 2.5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
After restore is done, the T2 Mac should start macOS installation.

Try again to start in SMC bypass mode.
Check voltage on big coils when fan spins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
SMC bypass mode did not work.

Voltages on all big coils are good.

After the fan spins meter stays at 0.63 amps for a few seconds then drops to 0amps. Afterwards only goes up to 0.14amps back to 0amps and so on up until charger disconnected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: After amps drop to 0 L8100 remains at 0V as the board cycles.. Could that be a bad <TRANSISTOR>Q8100</TRANSISTOR> even though it goes up to 1.1V when charger first plugged in?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: Try connecting battery (known good) and charger at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: Already did, and same type of behavior happens except amp draw a little higher.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
Good battery resolved that problem.

Once the board is powered up the apple logo appears for several minutes (normally only appears a few seconds) and once  internet recovery mode begins there is a another long delay before givin the option to choose wifi network. Trackpad cursor moves all over on its own. Click not working but caps light on keyboard works. Tried known good trackpad and keyboard but same behavior.

L6700 was replaced just in case  but no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: Did you change trackpad flex?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message: yes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DFU problems
threads.message:
Try again DFU restore.
Clean trackpad flex and MLB connector.
Test with another battery and charger.
